problem.title: An Athlete Pulling on A Rope - Balancing Forces to Find Minimum \mu_s.

p.p: A 100\text{-kg} athlete pulls a rope attached to a strong pole at an angle of 15^{\circ} from horizontal such that the tension in the rope devlops to 800\text{ N}.
(a) Find nomal and frictional forces on the athlete by the floor.

(b) What must be minimum value of the coefficient of ststic friction betweeen the sole of the shoes of the athlete and the floor so that the athlete does not slip on the floor while he is pulling on the rope?

hint.p: Draw a Free-Body Diagram of the athlete.

solution.p: (a) We start by identifying forces on the block, where I have used symbols for the forces: W for weight, T for weight, N_L for the normal on the left foot, N_R for the normal on the right foot, S_L for the static friction on the left foot, and S_R for the static friction on the right foot.

In the translational motion, we can combine the normal forces into one and call that N=N_L+N_R, and similary for the static friction, S=S_L+S_R. We will have to keep they separate when we look at rotation.

Since acceleration of the block is zero, the forces are balanced. Since only T is not along one of the axes, we will need to work out its components. Let \theta = 15^{\circ}.
T_x = T\,\cos\,\theta,\ \ T_y = T\,\sin\,\theta.
Now, we can write the equations of motion along the two axes.
T\,\cos\,\theta - S = 0, T\,\sin\,\theta + N - W = 0,
Here, the values of T , \theta, and W=mg, are known. Therefore, we solve the first equation to get S , and the second one for N .
S = T\,\cos\,\theta = 800 \times \cos\,15^{\circ} = 773\text{ N}, N = W - T\,\sin\,\theta = 100\times 9.81 - 800 \times \sin\,15^{\circ} = 461\text{ N}.

(b)The definition of \mu_s requires the maximum static friction.
\mu_s = \dfrac{S^{\text{max}}}{N}.
From the problem description, we need the minimum \mu_s . That means, if we assume the S we found was the S^{\text{max}}, then the \mu_s we will get will be the minimum required for the static condition to hold.
\mu_s^{\text{min}} = \dfrac{S^{\text{found}}}{N} = \dfrac{773}{461} = 1.68.
